label.intro:
We use the Indian Cattle data to demonstrate the importance of measuring variability. For this we look at two variables:

Price at Dairy Cooperation: Price of one liter of milk in Indian rupee;

Pasture everyday: Whether the cows pasture every day (0 = "No", 1 = "Yes")

When looking at the data, we see that the mean price at a dairy cooperation for cows that pasture every day is 23.4 Indian Rupees.

For cows that do not pasture every day, it is 23.2 Indian Rupees.

For those who did not answer the pasture every day, it is 23.4 Indian Rupees.

These seem very similar. However, when we then look at the standard deviation, we see that there is a larger range in price for cows that pasture everyday than those who do not (0.858 vs 0.463 respectively).

We can visualise this in the following plot:



The mean only tells one part of the story of the data and relationships, another big component that should not be overlooked is in the variability. It is important to measure the variability of the data.
